title: French Anti-Piracy Organisation Hadopi Uses Pirated Font In Own Logo
content:
[http://www.korben.info/le-logo-de-lhadopi-est-illegal.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20100125185351/http:/www.korben.info/le-logo-de-lhadopi-est-illegal.html "http://www.korben.info/le-logo-de-lhadopi-est-illegal.html")

They seem to have used an unlicensed font for their anti-piracy-law.
author: Arno Enslin

comments.content: But those aren't the same font...

I got the link from a German weblog. And I don’t understand French. "They seem" means, that I am not sure, if I can trust the info from the blog. So, if the info from the blog is untrue, please explain in detaily why. Then I send a message to the blogger. It is one of the private German top ten blogs.

Yes, I remember skimming some headlines about Hadopi turning out to have been using an illegal logo. I don't have much time now, but the article says the typeface used is [Bienvenue](http://web.archive.org/web/20100125185351/http:/www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/Bienvenue), designed by Jean-François Porchez for exclusive use by France Télécom.
The Hadopi logo saga in full and in English on [The FontFeed](http://web.archive.org/web/20100125185351/http:/kuex.us/62ca). You're welcome, non-French speakers. ;^)
